My phone buzzes with a message from Jamie, and my heart sinks as I read it. “I can’t believe you’d say that to me.” I scroll up, re-reading my last text—meant as a joke, but I see now how it could sound harsh. Jamie’s always valued honesty between us, and I know if I don’t call right now to clear things up, the misunderstanding will fester. I reach for my phone, thumb hovering over the call button.

But just then, the cabin door slides open. Mr. Patel, the transit authority supervisor, steps in, clipboard in hand. “Surprise audit,” he says, his eyes already scanning the control panel. My pulse quickens. I’m expected to be the model operator—focused, alert, no distractions, especially not personal calls. The rules are clear: no phone use while operating the train, especially during an audit.

I glance at my phone, Jamie’s hurt message still glowing on the screen. My friend needs me to explain, to be there, but my job demands unwavering professionalism. I feel the weight of both expectations pressing in, my mind racing as I stand frozen between the two worlds.
